Black body radiation merely describes the wavelengths of emr a heated object emits. And in that sense our sun would be considered yellow-green, as its intensity peaks at the wavelengths associated with yellow and green. Color however, in the more metaphysical sense of the word, is in the eye of the beholder (no pun untended), and is merely the interpretation of electrical signals created by our eyes. Our eyes are incapable of properly measuring light, and we therefore experience the sun to be white/yellow......well long story short....colours are weird...

When brown dwarfs are implemented into this mod, we need a minimum radius for brown dwarfs/red-brown dwarfs and normal stars, as well as a maximum for red-brown/brown dwarfs.

Minimum for normal stars should be 18000 KM, minimum for brown dwarfs/red-brown dwarfs should be 5000 KM, and maximum for brown/red-brown dwarfs should be 20000 KM. There should also be a minimum mass for normal stars and a min/max mass for brown/red-brown dwarfs. Couldn't you guys use the naturally expected radius just divided down to kerbal scale? (1:10 based, very roughly, on Earth/Kerbin)

So in the case of brown dwarfs, which are expected to be roughly the size of Jupiter (despite being much more massive) would give a radius of around 70,000km. Kerbal scale that down to 7,000km and you have a star that is about 2.3 times the diameter of Jool.

It wouldn't be too hard to a compile a list of kerbal-scaled star radii.

Sun to Kerbol is a very different scale than Earth to Kerbin though.

Kerbin is pretty standard, same gravitational pull on the surface as Earth but ~10 times smaller in radius, which means 1/100 the mass.

Kerbol is about 1/100 the mass of the Sun, but about 1/3 the radius, which results in a very different surface gravity (2 g's instead of 28). If Kerbol were using the same relative scale as Kerbin, it should be the same mass it is now but 1/10 the radius of the Sun.

So if we wanted to use Kerbin as the standard, Kerbol would have to be shrunk by about 3 times in radius. Then all the other stars and planets could be scaled up like that (1/10 the radius and 1/100 the mass of their real-life counterparts).

Actually... You can... at least in CE... The other's download link disappeared before I discovered this code that works:

CelestialBody
{
 GeeASL = 1
	bodyDescription=Ah, finally some rings... According to the fish the name translates into Kerbal as ratnes or "to stand". Significant? I doubt it...  Based on Polyphemus from Avatar. Texture from Celestia pack by Milosz21.
}

//This planet is not configurable





Orbit
{
    inclination = 1.5
    eccentricity = 0.01
    semiMajorAxis = 220003242000
    LAN = 82
    argumentOfPeriapsis = 58
    meanAnomalyAtEpoch = 1.4
    epoch = 0
    referenceBody = Sun
}

This is what I use
For the Sentar stuff, you can just add orbital parameters to its config file.
